perturbation.original_text: 2.10 "Improvement" or "Improvements" means any modification of a process or other technology described in a Patent, and any modification to Technical Information.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.10 "Improvement" or "Improvements" means any alteration of a process or other technology described in a Patent, and any addition to Technical Information.
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'modification' and 'alteration' are interchanged, and 'modification' and 'addition' are used instead of 'modification'. This creates ambiguity because 'alteration' is a broader and more vague term, while 'addition' would only mean adding, not changing anything.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Patent Law, Contract Law - Ambiguity in Definition

perturbation.original_text: 3.00 Company grants to Investor, for the duration of the Option Period, a worldwide, royalty-free, non-exclusive, irrevocable license (with the right to grant sublicenses to Affiliates) under the Patents to practice the methods therein described and claimed and to make and have made, use, offer to sell, sell and import products made using such methods, and to make Improvements, and to engage in any activity which would give rise to a claim of infringement (direct or indirect or otherwise) of one or more of the Patents in the absence of a license.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.00 Company grants to Investor, for the duration of the Option Period, a worldwide, royalty-required, exclusive, revocable license (without the right to grant sublicenses) under the Patents to practice the methods therein described and claimed and to make and have made, use, offer to sell, sell and import products made using such methods, and to make basic changes, and to engage in any activity which would give rise to a claim of infringement (direct or indirect or otherwise) of one or more of the Patents in the absence of a license.
perturbation.explanation: Several key terms are directly contradicted: 'royalty-free' becomes 'royalty-required,' 'non-exclusive' becomes 'exclusive,' and 'irrevocable' becomes 'revocable.' Further, the right to sublicense is removed, and the word 'Improvements' is replaced by 'basic changes'. These changes fundamentally alter the nature of the license granted, creating a contradiction with the original intent and standard definitions of these licensing terms under intellectual property law.

perturbation.original_text: 5.01 Investor shall own all right, title and interest in any Improvement made or acquired by the Investor ("Investor Improvement"). Investor hereby agrees to grant to Company a non-exclusive, irrevocable, royalty-free license under any Investor Improvement and any patent claiming such Investor Improvement, solely for use in rare earth mineral processing and rare earth separation, to make and have made, use, offer to sell, sell and import products made using the Investor Improvements.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.01 Investor shall own all right, title and interest in any Adjustment made or acquired by the Investor ("Investor Adjustment"). Investor hereby agrees to grant to Company a non-exclusive, temporary, royalty-bearing license under any Investor Adjustment and any patent claiming such Investor Adjustment, solely for use in rare earth mineral processing and rare earth separation, to make and have made, use, offer to sell, sell and import products made using the Investor Adjustments.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'Improvement' is replaced with the ill-defined term 'Adjustment'. 'Irrevocable' is replaced with 'temporary,' and 'royalty-free' is replaced with 'royalty-bearing'. The term 'temporary' is vague and does not specify any kind of duration, and goes against the nature of patent rights.
